        • Dataset.Tabular
        • Dataset.Sequence
        • Dataset.Image
    • 2. Selecting Features and Labels.
      • a) Select the Label column(s).
        • ORM
        • Deriving Labels
        • Reading Labels
      • b) Select the Feature column(s).
        • ORM
        • Specifying Features
        • Reading Features
    • 3. Slicing samples.
      • a) Define sliding time series Windows.
        • ORM
        • Specifying Windows
        • Reading Windows
      • b) Slice samples with a Splitset.
        • Stratification
        • Splitting Strategies
        • Reading Splitsets
      • c) fold_count triggers cross-validation.
        • ORM
        • Fold objects
        • Specifying Folds
        • Reading Folds
    • 4. Preprocessing - Interpolation.
      • ORM
      • a) Interpolate Labels with LabelInterpolater.
      • b) Interpolate Features with Interpolaterset.
    • 5. Preprocessing - Encoding.
      • Encoding
      • a) Encode labels with LabelCoder.
        • Creating a LabelCoder
      • b) Encode Features sequentially with FeatureCoders.
        • Filtering feature columns
    • 6. Preprocessing - Reshaping.
      • ORM
      • Reshaping by Index
      • Reshaping Explicitly
      • Multiplicative Reshaping
    • 7. Defining Architectures & Hyperparameters.
      • a) Define an Algorithm
        • Model Definition
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
      • b) Combinations of hyperparameters with Hyperparamset.
        • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 8. Queue of training Jobs.
      • a) Job objects.
      • b) Executing Jobs.
        • i) queue.run_jobs()
        • ii) DEPRECATED - queue.run_jobs(in_background=True).
      • c) Predictors are the trained models.
        • Fetching the trained model.
        • Fetching the hyperparameters.
      • d) Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
        • Fetching metrics.
    • 9. Metrics & Visualization

  • Query the Metastore
  • View page source

Query the Metastore

AIQC uses SQLite under the hood as a machine learning metastore. It persists critical information at every step of the workflow in order to help practitioners:

  • Interpret the performance of models

  • Reproduce experiments

  • Encode new samples during inference

For most use cases, the High-Level API and visualizations provide sufficient information. However, its good to know how to dig into the metastore when you need specific details.

Each object in the Low-Level API (e.g. Job, Predictor, Splitset, Feature, Dataset, and many more) is a relational table in a local SQLite file. The Low-Level API serves as an object-relational model (ORM) to easily traverse and inspect that metastore as Python objects. We’ll only scratch the surface of the Low-Level API here.

Let’s rapidly create a pre-trained queue of models so that we have some information to work with. We’ll use one of AIQC’s tests for the sake of brevity.

[2]:

from aiqc import mlops, datum, lab, tests, orm

[ ]:

queue = tests.tf_multi_tab.make_queue()
queue.run_jobs()

🧪 Inspecting the Modeling Process

How well did the models perform?

[ ]:

queue.plot_performance(min_score=0.94, max_loss=0.09)

[51]:

queue.metrics_to_pandas()

[51]:

Running a Job produces a model, which is saved in a Predictor object

[23]:

list(queue.jobs)

[23]:

[<Job: 2>,
 <Job: 3>,
 <Job: 4>,
 <Job: 5>,
 <Job: 6>,
 <Job: 7>,
 <Job: 8>,
 <Job: 9>]

[213]:

job = queue.jobs[0]

Jobs may be repeated for non-deterministic analysis, so they can produce many Predictors aka trained models.

You can fetch objects either by ID or by traversing relationships

[215]:

list(job.predictors)

[215]:

[<Predictor: 2>]

[216]:

predictor = orm.Predictor.get_by_id(2)

The model object

[54]:

predictor.get_model()

[54]:

<keras.engine.sequential.Sequential at 0x191368e90>

The hyperparameters that were fed to this specific job

[57]:

predictor.get_hyperparameters(as_pandas=True)

[57]:
param value
0 neuron_count 9.00
1 batch_size 3.00
2 learning_rate 0.03
3 epoch_count 30.00

How well did this particular model learn?

The user-defined, per-epoch training metrics

[ ]:

predictor.plot_learning_curve()

[55]:

predictor.history.keys()

[55]:

dict_keys(['loss', 'accuracy', 'val_loss', 'val_accuracy'])

[56]:

predictor.history['val_loss'][:10]

[56]:

[0.7967078685760498,

What features were driving the model?

[ ]:

prediction.plot_feature_importance(top_n=4)

How well did this particular model perform?

View the decoded predictions

[103]:

prediction = predictor.predictions[0]

[104]:

prediction.predictions.keys()

[104]:

dict_keys(['train', 'validation', 'test'])

[105]:

prediction.predictions['test'][:10]

[105]:

array(['setosa', 'setosa', 'setosa', 'setosa', 'setosa', 'setosa',
       'versicolor', 'versicolor', 'versicolor', 'versicolor'],
      dtype=object)

[ ]:

prediction.plot_confusion_matrix()

[108]:

# etc
prediction.plot_roc_curve()
prediction.plot_precision_recall()

[108]:

<bound method Prediction.plot_precision_recall of <Prediction: 2>>

What kind of Algorithm was trained?

[4]:

algorithm = queue.algorithm

[5]:

algorithm.library

[5]:

'keras'

[6]:

algorithm.analysis_type

[6]:

'classification_multi'

What did the architecture look like?

[7]:

algorithm.get_code().keys()

[7]:

dict_keys(['fn_build', 'fn_lose', 'fn_optimize', 'fn_train', 'fn_predict'])

[8]:

print(
    algorithm.get_code()['fn_optimize']
)

def fn_optimize(**hp):
        optimizer = tf.keras.optimizers.Adamax(hp['learning_rate'])
        return optimizer

What hyperparameters were tested?

[87]:

queue.algorithm.hyperparamsets[0].hyperparameters

[87]:

{'neuron_count': [9, 12],
 'batch_size': [3],
 'learning_rate': [0.03, 0.05],
 'epoch_count': [30, 60]}

💾 Inspecting the Data

What samples were fed to the algorithm?

[88]:

splitset = queue.splitset

How was the data divided into splits?

[92]:

splitset.sizes

[92]:

{'validation': {'percent': 0.18, 'count': 27},
 'test': {'percent': 0.12, 'count': 18},
 'train': {'percent': 0.7, 'count': 105}}

Which sample indices belong to which split?

[98]:

splitset.samples['test'][:10]

[98]:

[4, 6, 23, 32, 38, 49, 54, 64, 71, 78]

What Features were used to train the model?

There are multiple Features because AIQC support multi-modal analysis

[113]:

feature = splitset.get_features()[0]

[114]:

feature.columns

[114]:

['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width']

[115]:

feature.columns_excluded

[115]:

['species']

What were the Labels?

[116]:

label = splitset.label

[118]:

label.columns

[118]:

['species']

[119]:

label.unique_classes

[119]:

['setosa', 'versicolor', 'virginica']

What Dataset did these Features and Labels come from?

[120]:

dataset = feature.dataset

[121]:

dataset.dataset_type

[121]:

'tabular'

[123]:

dataset.file_count

[123]:

1

This dataset was created from an in-memory dataframe so there is no file path associated with it

[129]:

dataset.source_path

[135]:

file = dataset.files[0]

[136]:

file.is_ingested

[136]:

True

[137]:

file.shape

[137]:

{'rows': 150, 'columns': 5}

[138]:

file.columns

[138]:

['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width', 'species']

[139]:

file.dtypes

[139]:

{'sepal_length': 'float64',
 'sepal_width': 'float64',
 'petal_length': 'float64',
 'petal_width': 'float64',
 'species': 'object'}

How were the Labels and Features encoded during training?

[177]:

job = queue.jobs[0]

[183]:

job.fittedlabelcoders[0]

[183]:

<FittedLabelCoder: 2>

[186]:

labelcoder = job.fittedlabelcoders[0].labelcoder

[187]:

labelcoder.only_fit_train

[187]:

False

[189]:

labelcoder.sklearn_preprocess

[189]:

OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)

[190]:

labelcoder.matching_columns

[190]:

['species']

[201]:

fitted_encoder = job.fittedlabelcoders[0].fitted_encoders

[203]:

fitted_encoder

[203]:

OneHotEncoder(sparse=False)

[202]:

fitted_encoder.categories_

[202]:

[array(['setosa', 'versicolor', 'virginica'], dtype=object)]

The fit information is CRITICAL for:

  • Decoding raw predictions into human-readable insight.

  • Encoding new samples during inference.
